>>178154562
PT are just terribly written and fail to communicate George's intentions, which is that obsessive attachments is bad and leads to ruin. Basically, when handling such a theme you might not want to center the point of criticism on a child slave that was just snatched up from his mother, because no audience is going view that scenario and see a boy as wrong for those sort of feelings.

That bizarre framing from George was terrible optics for the Jedi because all the audience saw was a bunch of cold, emotionless monks bullying a child when they rejected him, and since Mace Windu does all the talking for the council in meetings, he becomes the face of these weird monks attacking a child for missing his mother, a child who up to this point has been built up as the character who the audience most identifies with.

I honestly don't know why George took this approach. He didn't even present anything that could somewhat clarify the Jedi's stance, like give some dialogue from one of the Jedi's about how much damage a single dark sider can do so we as the audience can understand what's at risk when a candidate doesn't meet their entry conditions. But all we get is some confusing shit from Yoda about anger leads to fear then trannyism or whatever. It's too abstract, the audience needed something logical here.

This is why till this day the fandom is still completely confused about the attachment philosophy, damn near everyone on twitter was stunned to see Luke practicing those teachings with Grogu because they're convinced that the PT were arguing those teachings were bad and is what caused Anakin to turn but the movies were saying the complete opposite. In other words, Mace is hated because George is a terrible story teller.

>This is why till this day the fandom is still completely confused about the attachment philosophy
It's pretty much all contained in Yoda's advice to Anakin: "Let go of what you fear to lose." It's fine to be attached to something, but you must not dwell on and allow that attachment to drive you into ruinous action nor overwhelm you. That's not to say it is a completely passive ideology, since you must also not allow what you fear to lose by taking righteous action prevent you from doing it. Ultimately it comes down to trusting in the will of the Force, and accepting that what will be lost will be lost.

>>178162132
There's a pipeline.
Once BR2049 dropped and started gaining lots of traction on here, Gosling-posting spread to other sites like Reddit and Twitter. There's a large amount of lonely people on the internet today so the movie resonated with a lot of people, memes were easy to produce.
This opened the floodgates for a bunch of other movies that featured similar themes of isolation and detachment. Taxi Driver, Drive, American Psycho, etc. Joker was also very popular.
In short: since so many young people today feel so disenfranchised and misunderstood, joking about your own mental health has become trendy. Pretending to be insane and acting like you're simply masking around others is a common joke among young people nowadays, at least online.
American Psycho is relatable to more people now than two decades ago, since it''s literally about a mentally ill man trying to fit in.
There's also the whole incel alpha/beta/sigma shit. Sigma is a term used to describe a man who doesn't care about woman and simply goes his own way. The term quickly became overused and then evolved to refer to mentally ill loners (who are still masculine and attractive). "Based" experienced a similar evolution, since it went from being used as a way express agreement to being used a way to jokingly agree with someone who's being racist.
The sigma grindset memes became very popular on Twitter and routinely featured characters like Guts, Mr. Peaky Blinders, Drive and Patrick Bateman.
Essentially, two different memes evolved around the same time, featured the same character (Bateman), and became very popular, and then remained very viral on Twitter and Tiktok.
That's it I'm not writing any more

>>178160474
She won an appeal, so the verdict was thrown out, and got the opportunity for a new trial. She's settling instead of relitigating, where she'd probably lose too (note that in civil court you are found liable or not liable, not guilty or not guilty). In civil court a decision not to contest something is not the same as actually admitting it's true. You can have a lawsuit where someone alleges something against you in their complaint, and you agree that it's true so you're not going to contest it, then in a second lawsuit they can allege the same thing, and you can then say it's not true and fight it. Your admission that it was true in a previous lawsuit can't be used as evidence, or have the issue precluded.

Japan has a world class film history and a beloved literary scene. I really think you're underselling the sheer amount of cultural export they've had since the 60s. If you like manga and you're able to read a manga which is obviously infused with some Japanese cultural experience which you find fascinating, why not keep an open mind and consider reading a Japanese novel which moves in the same direction? It's like a kid who only eats chicken nuggets even though the flavors and textures that they enjoy in chicken nuggets might be found in other types of food too.

>>178158280
Idols were largely about being cross media. The mainstream ones are pretty girls where their looks are their focus and you'll see them in a lot of stuff: music acts, actresses, advertising, as tarento, etc. Think of the Disney/Nick system.

The indie scene is a lot different as most groups are run by small management companies or themselves. It's much more focused on live performances which can vary in style from act to act. There's plenty who just do their songs and dances. Migma Shelter's live sets are mixes where each song is mixed directly into the next like a DJ set. Hanako-san's are basically Gallagher shows where you bring food and give it to her and she smashes, dumps it, or spits it on you and/or the crowd. Rowdier groups might have a lot of crowdsurfing and things like that.

The smaller nature of the shows also tends to mean that it's easier for a rapport to be formed between fans and performers.

>>178136372
Child of three, they had called her, daughter of death, slayer of lies, bride of fire. So many threes. Three fires, three mounts to ride, three treasons. “The dragon has three heads,” she sighed. “Do you know what that means, Jorah?”
“Your Grace? The sigil of House Targaryen is a three-headed dragon, red on black.”
“I know that. But there are no three-headed dragons.”
“The three heads were Aegon and his sisters.”
“Visenya and Rhaenys,” she recalled. “I am descended from Aegon and Rhaenys through their son Aenys and their grandson Jaehaerys.”
“Blue lips speak only lies, isn’t that what Xaro told you? Why do you care what the warlocks whispered? All they wanted was to suck the life from you, you know that now.”
“Perhaps,” she said reluctantly. “Yet the things I saw . . .”
“A dead man in the prow of a ship, a blue rose, a banquet of blood . . . what does any of it mean, Khaleesi? A mummer’s dragon, you said. What is a mummer’s dragon, pray?”
“A cloth dragon on poles,” Dany explained. “Mummers use them in their follies, to give the heroes something to fight.”
Ser Jorah frowned.
Dany could not let it go. “His is the song of ice and fire, my brother said. I’m certain it was my brother. Not Viserys, Rhaegar. He had a harp with silver strings.”
Ser Jorah’s frown deepened until his eyebrows came together. “Prince Rhaegar played such a harp,” he conceded. “You saw him?”
She nodded. “There was a woman in a bed with a babe at her breast. My brother said the babe was the prince that was promised and told her to name him Aegon.”
“Prince Aegon was Rhaegar’s heir by Elia of Dorne,” Ser Jorah said. “But if he was this prince that was promised, the promise was broken along with his skull when the Lannisters dashed his head against a wall.”
“I remember,” Dany said sadly. “They murdered Rhaegar’s daughter as well, the little princess. Rhaenys, she was named, like Aegon’s sister. There was no Visenya, but he said the dragon has three heads. What is the song of ice and fire?”

>>178152880
>No fuck off. Eating animals is natural, eating meat grown in a vat sounds disgusting and like it might present problems down the line like asbestos
I get it, I'm a big meat eater (cooked an amazing lamb roast a couple days ago), but cloned meat has potential for being amazing. The way it works is they take the cells from whatever animal they want to make meat from, and then feed those cells blood which the cells then use to replicate as they normal would. The problem is that without a bodily system to organise them they cells basically just create a blob of poorly structured mince meat which is not particularly pleasant feeling to eat. The other problem is the amount of blood still needed to be harvested for the sake of feeding the cells.
Figuring out a way of synthesizing a nutrient bath to feed the cells and then getting them to organise into the shape and texture we want (either through printing or nanites building the meat) would revolutionise not just food, but several other industries.
First and foremost, the same technology would be able to grow cloned organs and limbs, using the patient's own cells. No more organ rejection or shortages. Entire body parts replaced. Plus if the organs are grown from cells taken from the patient is younger and stored (taken from a 15 year old) then used to grow organs for an 80 year old that would extend life expectancy because of fewer cell replication errors (older recipients of blood transfusions from younger donors often show better health).
Transport of food would be cheaper. Growing steaks to square or at the very least perfectly uniform in shape and size would make for far easier transport logistics, cutting down on fuel expenditure and emissions.

>>178157504
That whole aspect is explicitly spelled out yet still open to interpretation.
Colm wanted to create art that transcended his lifetime, believing in some value in people knowing his work after he passed. He was so convinced of this, he was willing to sacrifice things within his life to attempt that (without certainty of the outcome).
Padraic by contrast was living in the moment and had no concern beyond the immediate. This is kinda lampshaded by the civil war going on over the water and his lack of concern/regard for that. Similarly his inability to understand Colm's perspective on transcendental art, it's just beyond his perspective.
Siobahn is living somewhat mindlessly but content in the present and via her arc is tempted away by something almost as ephemeral as Colm's desires - The promise of a better life in far away places. Padraic is similarly unable to conceive of this and understand in any way.
You could probably also make a fairly straightforward argument that the fourth character following a parallel, contrasting, comparable arc is Dominic - Only his brighter future is face-down in the lake, given the reality of his life right now. Padraic was similarly unawares of this being his trajectory, as in many cases were the viewers.
